learning_outcomes.description: Demonstrate knowledge and understanding of the basic principles that inform commercial law;
Analyse and interpret case law and statute law relevant to commercial law;
Bring to bear, where appropriate, a critical appraisal of modern commercial law;
Identify and apply relevant legal principles in the analysis of a given factual situation, and present an appreciation of the legal position; and
Take instructions and commence the drafting of a commercial agreement

assessments.task_description:
Students will be asked to draft a document which will give effect to a set of instructions provided by a simulated client. The exercise will be 500 - 700 words in length.


This assessment task evaluates students' abilities, skills and knowledge without the aid of Artificial Intelligence (AI). Students are advised that the use of AI technologies to develop responses is strictly prohibited and may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.due_date:
2/09/2024 - 5/09/2024

The take home assessment will be released on the course Blackboard page on Monday, 2 September 2024 at 2pm, and due on Thursday, 5 September 2024 at 2pm.
assessments.task_description:
There will be one or two short essay questions but mostly the assessment will consist of problem style questions. It will cover the lecture material delivered in weeks 1 to 6. It is a take home assessment and NOT a research paper. There will be no marks for extensive citations and references.

 

This assessment task evaluates student’s abilities, skills and knowledge without the aid of Artificial Intelligence (AI). Students are advised that the use of AI technologies to develop responses is strictly prohibited and may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: The assignment must be submitted electronically via the assessment submission link on the course Learn.UQ (Blackboard) site.

assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.due_date:
18/10/2024 - 22/10/2024

The take home assessment will be released on the course Blackboard page on Friday, 18 October 2024 at 2pm, and due on Tuesday, 22 October 2024 at 2pm.
assessments.task_description:
It will assess only those topics which were not assessed in the mid-semester take home assessment. Comprising mostly problem-style questions and one or two short essay style questions.

It is a take home assessment and NOT a research paper. There will be no marks for extensive citations and references.

 

This assessment task evaluates student’s abilities, skills and knowledge without the aid of Artificial Intelligence (AI). Students are advised that the use of AI technologies to develop responses is strictly prohibited and may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

learning_activities.topic:
Seminars

The programme of seminars for the course is set out in the course learning guide. This is available from the course Blackboard site.

Seminar topics are:

  1. Introduction to Commercial Law and Commercial Agreements.
  2. Agency
  3. Sale of Goods and Transfer of Title in Goods
  4. Bailment
  5. Insurance
  6. Business to Business Misleading Conduct
  7. Business to Business Unconscionable Conduct and Unfair Contract Terms
  8. Franchising

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05
